ygData.subject: Heritrix under Apache License?
ygData.msgSnippet: At some point in 2008, the Internet Archive s Heritrix team would like to transition the Heritrix project to the Apache License (version 2), rather than the

Subject: Heritrix under Apache License?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=137285340; y=CeklKYuwWHlJPYCMaG-ooKz4uje1fT4ICXOdHzSOATQ6
X-Yahoo-Profile: gojomo

At some point in 2008, the Internet Archive's Heritrix team would like 
to transition the Heritrix project to the Apache License (version 2), 
rather than the Lesser/Library GPL (version 2.1). We'd like your 
opinions before we proceed.

The IA and its major partners in the project (the libraries of the Int'l 
Internet Preservation Consortium) are all equally comfortable with the 
Apache License as the LGPL, and using the Apache license would allow 
easier integration with other Apache-centric projects of keen interest 
to our community, such as Lucene/Nutch/Hadoop. (We also extensively 
benefit from Apache project libraries in Heritrix, and in the spirit of 
reciprocity would like our work to be freely reusable by other Apache 
projects.)

For reference, the relevant Apache License is here:

   http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html

Any transition would be gradual, as we ensure notable non-IA 
contributors approve the relicensing, and communicate that future 
contributions will become part of the project under the new license.

To maintain the widest possible license compatibility in the face of 
arcane and sometimes disputed matters of interpretation (such as whether 
Apache License 2 is compatible with GPL 2), we may also continue to 
offer LGPL as an simultaneous license option, indefinitely.

Do people have opinions, positive or negative, about this contemplated 
move? Any concerns that should be addressed?

- Gordon @ IA
